result.execSummary:
The defendant Brady W Wolfe was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Homicide by Negligent Operation/Vehicle, a class G felony, Wisconsin Statutes 940.10(1).
  • Endanger Safety/Use/Dangerous Weapon, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 941.20(1)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes:
$268 represents Court ordered court costs.
A total of $268 is PAYABLE TO CLERK OF COURTS OFFICE - 30 days to pay or request a payment plan. 
Due June 9, 2018.
All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

Plus supervision fees.
If probation is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. 
All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.
Huber granted for work release; or for any purpose approved by Chippewa County Sheriff Office.
Any assessment and counseling as required and follow through and complete all required treatment.

No contact with: victim's family unless approved by the victim's family and probation agent.
Not to possess or consume any illegal drugs.  
Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  
Not to possess or consume any controlled substance not prescribed by authorized medical personnel.  
Not to possess or consume any alcohol.  
Not to go on any premises where primary purpose is the sale of alcohol.

Defendant Brady W Wolfe in court with attorney Michael R. Cohen.  Wade Newell appeared for the State of Wisconsin. DA Newell states case and notes appearances. 
DA Newell addresses pending motions and requests that the motion hearing currently scheduled remain on the calendar and all motions be addressed at that time. Atty Cohen responds. 
Court orders: All expert witnesses to be disclosed by February 9, 2018. All lay witnesses to be disclosed by March 1, 2018. Supplemental witnesses to be addressed as they occur. Pre-trial motions to be filed by February 9, 2018. Proposed jury instructions and special verdict to be filed by March 9, 2018. Voir Dire questions to be asked by the court be submitted by March 9, 2018. 
Bond continued.
